intro: Marrubium hierapolitanum, commonly known as the Hierapolis horehound, is a perennial herb native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes many aromatic plants such as parsley and carrots. The plant is characterized by its finely divided, gray-green leaves and small, yellowish flowers that appear in umbrella-like clusters. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in dry, sunny habitats. Marrubium hierapolitanum has a long history of use in traditional medicine for its purported digestive and anti-inflammatory properties.
